content:
Edited to correct the size of test 5 (48 -> 63).

It might be more appropriate for CoC than for classic puzzles, but anyway, as a puzzle, it's certainly more "easy" than "medium".
EDIT: Moved to "easy" as several people here and in the forum seem to agree on that.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is  more appropriate for CoC than for a solo puzzle, but I see some other approver thought it differently, OK for me as it is. Also, looks more 'easy' than 'medium' for me, being quite simple string manipulation, but if a language has no binary to decimal conversion, that makes it a bit longer.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's quite easy for a medium puzzle.
But it's an interesting and funny puzzle.

This puzzle was fun!

I took a pass editing the statement for grammar. (Not sure if I can just edit the changes in.)
---

You have been looking on the network [[packet]] a game is sending, and you have been thinking about making a system to automatically pick things up for you!

You have found the [[packet]] is one big string of binary data of instructions.
Each instruction is formatted in this way:
<<[instruction id (3 bits)][packet length (4 bits)][packet info (packet length bits)]>>.

What you need to do is extract the item drop instructions, they have id <<101>>, and their <<packet info>> is the item id you will need! This id might be different lengths, so look at the <<packet length>>.

What you need to send back is a set of pickup instructions, id <<001>>. Remember the packet length!
<<001[item id length][item id]>>

For example: "10100010101001011" we have the id and length:
"101 0001 0101001011" which means we should take 1 bit for the item id, so
"101 0001 0".
 Then we look at the rest of the packet
"101001011" and split that up into "101 0010 11" and get the second id "11".

Then we just send the response "001 0001 0" and "001 0010 11".

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I agree this problem, but for clash of code is too long, try to make it smaller and try to make it a puzzle too, a medium i'll say, keep doing :)

You have sequences with garbage before or after the drop instruction. Therefore we can't know that you want the first and last potential sequence in test 2, and don't want the middle one.
"10100010101001011" -> 101 0100 1011
idk what you mean the middle one? there are only 2 drop instructions and the output has both of them?

ah I see what you mean, well let me break this down for you.
"10100010101001011" we have the id and length:
"101 0001 0101001011" witch means we should take 1 bit for the item id, so
"101 0001 0"
 then we look at the rest of the packet
"101001011"  and split that up into "101 0010 11" and get the second id "11"

then we just send the response "001 0001 0" and "001 0010 11"

It took me that last comment to understand the question.
I think such an example is needed in the goal description.
I see, I have updated it :)

Sorry my comment was unclear. Here's what I meant:

In the "In between" test, we need to split the input into 11100011, 101001011, 0010011101  where only the middle piece is used. The beginning and end are garbage.

The "more than 1 drop" test is obviously from the title meant to be split into two useful pieces and no garbage. But there is an alternative way to split it such that there is only one useful piece in the middle, surrounded by garbage.

Since an algorithm doesn't read the titles, it has no way of knowing which type of input it's getting in each case.

We could set an algorithm to use the first "101" it finds and then skip ahead to the end of that instruction. But that would skip too far ahead on an input like "10110100010".

And it also doesn't pick out the same sequences you want in your "that is a long one" test. The first valid sequence there is "1011001010100111"

the thing is that the "garbage" are also instructions, just ones that you don't care about. 

what you do is read their lengths and jump that long forward
